Suzuki coupling reaction is widely applied for constructing biaryl skeletons in various fields. Designing and developing highly effective catalysts are essential regarding the Suzuki coupling reaction. Here, we report a simple light irradiation approach to achieve the highly efficient Suzuki coupling reaction via the application of low valence Pd homogeneous catalyst. The catalyst exhibited a TOF value of 76,000 h−1. We systematically investigated the impact of various experimental conditions on catalytic performance and further clarify the evolution of Pd species during the light irradiation and catalytic reaction process. This work provides a facile strategy for designing highly effective catalysts for the Suzuki coupling reaction and understanding the detailed evolution process of Pd during the reaction process. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd homogeneous catalyst Suzuki coupling Photo activation Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Suzuki coupling, a kind of crucial conversion applied in various fields such as the preparation of pharmaceuticals, fine chemicals, and functional materials, [1,2] is extraordinarily convenient for constructing biaryl skeletons by the chemical reaction between aryl halides and aryl boronic acids [3–5]. It is of great significance to design catalytically high performance catalysts for Suzuki coupling, arousing extensive research interest [6,7]. Among various catalysts, palladium (Pd) has attracted much attention due to its excellent performance [8–11]. The primary process for the Pd catalyzed reaction involves the oxidation-addition of halides, transmetalation, and reductive elimination, [12,13] in which the oxidation-addition step acts as the rate-determining step of the catalytic reaction [14]. Generally, the generated catalytic active Pd0 species undergo Pd(0)-Pd(Ⅱ) cycle during the catalytic process. When low valence Pd-based catalyst is applied, electron transfer from the low valence material to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of the absorbed aryl halide molecules becomes easier, resulting in the absorbed aryl halide molecules’ chemical bonds weakening and making the dissociation of substrates with lower activation energy [15–17]. At present, Pd catalysts can be divided into two categories, including homogeneous and heterogeneous. For most heterogeneous catalysts, catalytic active species Pd exist in the form of nanoparticles, and limited exposure of active sites leads to low atomic utilization and TOF values of catalysts [15,18,19]. Furthermore, some researchers believed the Pd ions leached from Pd nanoparticles to the reaction liquid and participated in the catalytic cycle [20,21]. That is to say, the genuinely catalytic active species is isolated Pd atoms in the reaction solution. The main approach for homogeneous catalysts is to explore the low or zero-valent Pd coordination compounds via regulating ligands, such as phosphorous [22]. N-heterocyclic carbines [23] and so on. However, most ligands are unstable, expensive and toxic, and their turnover frequency (TOF) values are below 10,000 h−1 [24–30]. Recently, with the deepening of research, researchers have gained a deeper understanding of the mechanism of the Suzuki coupling reaction, including the determination of the catalytic active substance[31] and the study of the details of the catalytic reaction process [32], as well as the study of more economic catalysts for catalytic coupling reaction [33,34]. In addition, some research teams have introduced light during preparing catalysts or catalytic coupling reactions and have obtained good catalytic performance [35,36]. Here, we explored a facile photoactivation approach to prepare a low valent Pd homogeneous catalyst for Suzuki coupling. The TOF value of the Pd(acac)2 catalyst after the irradiation reaches up to 76,000 h−1 and increases 4 times compared to the sample without irradiation, surpassing all the reported values. Moreover, we investigated the evolution of Pd elements during the catalytic process and clarified its deactivation mechanism under various reaction conditions. The work opens a new avenue for designing highly effective catalysts in both catalyst synthesis and catalytic reaction conditions perspective. 2 Experimental section 2.1 General All the chemicals and reagents were used after being purchased from companies without purification. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker AV 400 spectrometer (CDCl3 as the solvent containing TMS as the internal standard). Ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) spectra were obtained by TU-1901 double beam UV–vis spectrophotometer. UV–vis fluorescence emission spectra (irradiation wavelength: 325 nm) were tested on a Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained by Bruker INVENIO Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements at the Pd K edge (24,340 eV) were performed in the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20, 200 kV) was employed for the morphologies of the samples. Transmission electron microscopy was performed for the homogeneous catalyst by dipping the solution on a copper grid and allowing solvent evaporation. For the sample after the reaction, at the end of the reaction, we took some supernatant and added a large amount of ethanol. The potassium carbonate in the supernatant precipitated because it could not dissolve in ethanol. The supernatant was applied for TEM characterization. 2.2 Preparation of the homogeneous catalyst We dissolved 6 mg palladium acetylacetone (Pd(acac)2) in 10 mL ethyl alcohol (denoted as Pd in E) or toluene (denoted as Pd in T) as the raw catalyst. Moreover, some of the abovementioned natural Pd-based materials were treated with simulated sunlight (AM 1.5 G, 110 mW/cm2) for a period (marked Rex in E and Rex in T; x represents the irradiation time in min). The prepared homogeneous catalysts were in a liquid state and applied for the Suzuki coupling reaction. 2.3 Evaluation of the performance of the homogeneous catalysts for the Suzuki coupling reaction 4 mL water, K2CO3 (0.4146 g, 3 mmol), phenylboronic acid (0.2561 g, 2.1 mmol) or its derivatives, and 1 mL ethanol were added to a 50 mL round-bottom flask successively. A certain amount of the as-prepared homogeneous catalyst solution, bromobenzene (0.3140 g, 2.0 mmol) or its derivatives, and 3 mL ethanol were mixed in flask B. After stirring the reaction system at a specific temperature for 8 min, we injected the liquid in flask B into it through a syringe, and the catalytic reaction started. The catalytic reaction product biphenyl and its derivatives are insoluble in the aqueous alcohol mixture used for the reaction. Therefore, all of the catalytic reaction products were separated from the reaction system by centrifugation when the reaction was finished. The isolated products were dried by vacuum and then weighed by four-digit balance to obtain the final yields, and the product's molecular structure was determined by NMR characterization. We did two parallel tests for all experiments and calculated the mean value of the two tests. The error ratio (difference between the actual test value and the mean value) to the mean value (the relative error) is less than 5%. TOFs are calculated by Eq. (1) and based on the total mole amount of palladium atoms in the homogeneous catalyst solution. (1) T O F = m / ( M t n c a t ) In Eq. (1), m is the mass of the reaction product in a specific reaction time, M is the relative molecular mass of the product, ncat is the molar of palladium in the reaction system, and t is the reaction time. 2.4 The kinetic experiment of the catalytic reaction We chose the homogeneous catalyst Re30 in E and tested its catalytic kinetic curve under an air atmosphere at 80 °C. After a certain period of reaction, the reaction bottle was taken out, and the bottle's temperature was suddenly lowered to stop the reaction. Subsequently, the stopped reaction liquid was taken out and centrifuged. We weighed the precipitation mass and calculated the conversion rate of the catalytic reaction in a specific reaction period. Thereout, the kinetic curve of the catalytic reaction was obtained. 3 Results 3.1 Preparation of low-valence Pd homogeneous catalyst by light irradiation We present a facile photoactivation approach to preparing a low-valence Pd homogeneous catalyst due to its high reduction potential [37–40]. Fig. 1 a shows the schematic experimental process for synthesizing the homogeneous catalyst Re30 in E (catalyst dissolved in ethanol and reduced by simulated sunlight for 30 min). The color of the homogeneous catalyst solution did not change significantly after the light irradiation. Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) characterization revealed that the Pd atoms did not agglomerate and remained monodisperse after light treatment (Fig. 1b and c). Additionally, as shown in Fig. 2 a and Fig. S1, the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) characterization results showed that the Pd K-edge position of Pd after light irradiation (Re30 in E) was between those of Pd foil and PdO. However, the Pd K-edge position of Pd in E (Pd(acac)2 dissolved in ethanol) was close to PdO. These results indicate that the oxidation state of Re30 in E decreases, which is consistent with the previous reports [41–44]. Furthermore, EXAFS characterization reveals more detailed coordination information surrounded by Pd atoms. As shown in Fig. 2b and Fig. S2, there is a prominent peak at ∼1.95 Å from the Pd-O contribution and no peak at ∼2.76 Å attributed to Pd-Pd interaction for the activated sample [45]. The EXAFS results further confirm that the Pd atoms were not reduced to Pd nanoparticles or nanoclusters under light irradiation, consistent with the HAADF-STEM characterizations. We can observe from the k-space EXAFS oscillation functions k2χ(k) that the oscillation amplitude in the low-k region (k < 5 Å−1) of the sample Re30 in E is decreased compared with the unreduced material (Fig. S3). Based on the EXAFS fitting results (Fig. 2c and Table S1), the Pd atom is coordinated by about 4 O atoms at the first coordination shell, with a bond length of 1.94 Å for catalyst Pd in E and 1.97 Å for Re30 in E. From the above characterization and fitting results, we can infer that the Pd-O interaction becomes weaker after light irradiation. Moreover, the light did not lead to the aggregation of Pd atoms. Based on 1H NMR characterization of the catalysts (Fig. S4), we can infer that all the acac ligands in the catalyst are in the enol form but not in the keto form. Mass spectrometry (MS) showed that the molecular formula of the catalyst molecules did not change after irradiation (Fig. S5). To clarify the effect of irradiation on Pd(acac)2 homogeneous catalyst, Fourier transforms infrared (FTIR) characterization was carried out. As shown in Fig. 1d, for the liquid sample pure Pd(acac)2 dissolved in ethanol, the peak centered at 1568 cm−1 is attributed to the CO stretching vibration band in the enol form [46,47]. With the extension of the light-induced reduction time, the peak ascribed to CO stretching vibration appears redshift. When the illumination reduction time was 70 min, the redshift reached the maximum value of 4 cm−1. As we all know, Pd(acac)2, a coordination compound, is the central metal atom Pd coordinates with two acetylacetone ligands. Each ligand donates two oxygen atoms to coordinate with the Pd atom [48]. The light-induced reduction of Pd(acac)2 decreasees the Pd oxidation state and weakens the interaction between the Pd and oxygen atoms, thus leading to the redshift of the peak attributed to the CO stretching vibration [49]. Combining all the above characterization results, we can get the mechanism of the photoactivation process: under the action of light, the electrons in palladium acetylacetone molecules are transferred from ligands to Pd atoms, the molecular configuration changes (Fig. S6) [50,51]. We infer that electrons come from two sources. One is a reducing solution agent (such as ethanol etc.), and another possibility is that it comes from electrons generated by photoexcitation. We tested the absorption spectra of acetylacetone palladium in toluene solution as shown in Fig. S7. From the absorption spectrum, it can be seen that it has strong light absorption in the ultraviolet range of 300–340 nm with the maximum absorption peak located at 326 nm. Moreover, since the reduction potential of Pd elements is very positive (0.951), Pd ion is easily reduced to zero valent Pd. The schematic diagram of the possible electron transfer process is shown in Fig. S6. Therefore, the generation of electrons by acetylacetone palladium after absorbing light or the solution agent will reduce the valence state of palladium under light irradiation. In addition, due to the weak reduction ability of the two reduction routes mentioned above, and the protection of ligands, palladium is still uniformly dispersed in the solution without generating palladium particles. 3.2 Catalytic activity and stability Table 1 shows the performances of the Suzuki coupling reaction between the substrate bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid catalyzed by the homogeneous Pd catalysts. The TOF value was as high as 76,000 h−1 for the Re30 in E catalyst (Entry 1) when reacted at 80 °C in the mixture of water and ethanol (V/V = 1:1). In contrast, the catalytic performance was worse when applied Pd in E as the catalyst. The TOF value was only 18,800 h−1 when reacted at the same condition (Entry 4). Moreover, the trend is similar when the reaction temperature is 50 °C (Entry 2 v.s. Entry 5) or 25 °C (Entry 3 v.s. Entry 6). It is thus apparent that irradiation treatment significantly promotes catalytic performance. Furthermore, through comparison, it is found that the performance of the photoactivation Pd(acac)2 catalyst is far beyond the catalytic activity of most materials reported in the literature (Table S2). In order to exclude the influence of other factors on the catalytic reaction, we did the following two blank experiments. No catalyst or anhydrous ethanol after irradiation for 30 min with the same amount as the Re30 in E was added to the catalytic reaction system for the reaction. No products were observed under the same reaction condition. The experimental results showed that the catalyst for the coupling reaction is the Pd species. Moreover, the catalyst Re30 in E had a high selectivity. When bromobenzene or phenylboronic acid were used as reactants alone, no reaction product biphenyl was formed under the same reaction conditions, indicating that the catalyst could not catalyze the self-coupling reaction of the reaction substrate. Furthermore, we evaluated the effect of reaction solvent on the Suzuki reaction. As shown in Table 1, The TOF value was only 8150 h−1 (Entry 7) when toluene was used as the catalytic solvent reacted at 80 °C. Compared with the aqueous alcohol mixture, the catalytic performance of Re30 in T decreased significantly. Moreover, the TOF value was 14600h−1 (Entry 8) when ethanol was applied as the reaction solution. Therefore, using an aqueous alcohol mixture as the reaction solvent plays a crucial role in improving the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Since ethanol is a reducing solvent, we treated the same light irradiation with toluene (T), a non-reducing solvent, as the catalyst's solution and tested their catalytic properties. Under the same reaction condition, the TOF value is 61,818 h−1 for catalyst Re30 in T (Entry 9) and 19,540 h−1 for Pd in T (Entry 10). The experimental results showed that the catalytic performance can be improved significantly after the light irradiation treatment regardless of whether the solvent is reductive. Furthermore, we investigated the impact of irradiation time on the performance of catalysts (Table S3). The catalyst under simulated sunlight irradiation for 30 min exhibited the best performance among the prepared catalysts. Combining the characterization results, we can draw the following inference. When the irradiation time is less than 30 min, the interaction of the Pd-O bond in complex Pd(acac)2 is stronger because the irradiation time is not long enough. However, when the irradiation duration is prolonged, the Pd(acac)2 will be reduced to Pd nanoparticles or Pd black with ethanol as the reducing agent. Based on the above-mentioned experimental results, the optimal reduction time is 30 min for preparing the homogeneous catalyst, which processed the most suitable structure to catalyze the Suzuki coupling reaction in our reaction condition. Subsequently, we found that air played an essential role in the catalytic performance of Re30 in E. The TOF value decreased to 18,200 h-1 for Re30 in E catalyst (Entry 11) when the Suzuki coupling reaction was carried out under an argon atmosphere. The plausible reason is that the Pd catalyst is more likely to be reduced to nanoparticles by ethanol in an inert gas atmosphere, thus affecting the catalytic performance of the catalyst. The stability of our photoactivation catalyst under air provides good convenience for its application. Finally, unfortunately, although the synthesized catalyst has excellent catalytic activity, it cannot be recycled. The experimental results indicated that: (1) The Pd(acac)2 in solution underwent a structural transformation after being treated with simulated sunlight and exhibited better catalytic performance than the natural homogeneous catalyst for the Suzuki coupling reaction due to the structural change. (2) The light-induced transformation could occur in ethanol or toluene. (3) Compared with toluene or pure ethanol, the light-induced catalyst performed better when water and ethanol (V/V = 1:1) were applied as the Suzuki coupling reaction solvent. The homogeneous catalyst Re30 in E has the best catalytic performance in the aqueous ethanol solution under an air atmosphere. Furthermore, we investigated the effect of reaction time on conversion rate. As shown in Fig. 2b, we observed a ∼7 min reaction induction time during the whole reaction process. After that, the product biphenyl accumulated rapidly within 3 min, and the reactant conversion reached 80% after 3 min. The final conversion for this reaction is 95% when the reaction time is 30 min. TEM characterization demonstrated that the Pd atoms aggregated into NPs with a diameter of ∼2 nm when the catalytic reaction finished (Fig. S8). The isolated Pd species underwent a series of structural changes and turned to aggregated NPs finally (Fig. 3 ). To verify whether the Pd particles have a catalytic activity, the Suzuki coupling reaction was performed again under the same conditions. After 30 min, no reaction product could be detected, meaning the Pd nanoparticles are not the catalytically active species. 3.3 Scope of the Suzuki reaction We next investigated the scope of substrates based on the photoactivation homogeneous catalyst (Re30 in E). As shown in Table 2 , a series of aryl halides and phenylboronic acids with various functional groups were converted to the desired products with high TOF values. The reaction substrates with an electron-withdrawing or electron-donating group all had high yields and high TOF values. The experimental results proved that our catalyst had a wide range of substrate applicability, which is beneficial for industrial applications. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism We deduced the reaction mechanism based on the experimental and characterization results (Scheme 1 ). Pd(acac)2 is a coordination compound with the central metal Pd's oxidation number of 2. The valence state would decrease and transform into Pd(x)(acac)2 (x<2) complex after light irradiation. The weakened Pd-O bond makes the Pd coordination unsaturated, so the reactant bromobenzene is more easily oxidized addition to the Pd atom for subsequent reaction. It is frequently considered that the ligand dissociation step (PdL2 → PdL + L) is a relatively slow step and may be accomplished via simple ligand dissociation or substrate-assisted ligand replacement [52–54]. The inference is consistent with the experimental observation of the induction period during the catalytic Suzuki coupling reaction. In the reaction process, ligand dissociation is accompanied by the adsorption and activation of bromobenzene, which is the rate-determining step of the catalytic reaction. Since the light-treated catalyst can adsorb the reactant bromobenzene, the aggregation and deactivation of Pd atoms have been slowed down due to steric hindrance. In contrast, the homogeneous catalysts without light treatment are more likely to agglomerate and deactivate after the ligands break away from the central Pd atoms. Subsequently, the transmetallation and reductive elimination process convert the Pd to zero valent species. The primary catalytic process is complete and followed by the next catalytic cycle. In the early stage of catalytic reaction, the catalyst has high catalytic performance because the reactant can act as a ligand to inhibit the aggregation of the active catalytic species of Pd. At the end of the catalytic reaction, since there are not enough reactant molecules to serve as ligands, the Pd(0) species dissociated in the reaction solvent can easily aggregate into Pd nanoparticles, and the homogeneous catalyst will be deactivated. 4 Conclusion This work presents a simple photoactivation method to synthesize a highly effective homogeneous Pd catalyst for the Suzuki coupling reaction. After light irradiation treatment, the TOF value of the catalyst is as high as 76,000 h−1 due to the high activity of the low-state Pd catalyst. Our findings open a new avenue for designing highly effective catalysts for the Suzuki coupling reaction. coredata.dc:description: Suzuki coupling reaction is widely applied for constructing biaryl skeletons in various fields. Designing and developing highly effective catalysts are essential regarding the Suzuki coupling reaction. Here, we report a simple light irradiation approach to achieve the highly efficient Suzuki coupling reaction via the application of low valence Pd homogeneous catalyst. The catalyst exhibited a TOF value of 76,000 h−1. We systematically investigated the impact of various experimental conditions on catalytic performance and further clarify the evolution of Pd species during the light irradiation and catalytic reaction process. This work provides a facile strategy for designing highly effective catalysts for the Suzuki coupling reaction and understanding the detailed evolution process of Pd during the reaction process.
coredata.dc:title: Highly effective photoativation Pd catalyst for Suzuki coupling reaction
